questions.text: A female patient presents with complaints of thick curdy white vaginal secretion. Microscopy of vaginal scraping shows budding yeasts and pseudohyphae. Which medium will be used to identify the likely species?
questions.solution:
• CHROMagar (Chromogenic Agar) is the preferred medium for identifying Candida species.
  • It differentiates various Candida species based on their colony color:
    • Candida albicans → Green colonies
    • Candida tropicalis → Blue to metallic blue colonies
    • Candida krusei → Pink, fuzzy colonies

  • This method allows for rapid identification of Candida species, which is essential for guiding appropriate antifungal treatment.

Incorrect Choices Explanation

  • Choice A: SDA (Sabouraud Dextrose Agar) – Incorrect
    • SDA is a general fungal culture medium that supports the growth of Candida but does not differentiate species.
  • Choice C: Brain Heart Infusion (BHI) Agar – Incorrect
    • BHI agar is a rich medium for fungal and bacterial growth, but it does not provide species-level identification.
  • Choice D: Bird Seed Agar – Incorrect
    • Bird seed agar is used for identifying Cryptococcus neoformans, which produces brown/black colonies due to melanin production, but it is not used for Candida species.

Key Takeaway

CHROMagar is the best medium for differentiating Candida species based on colony color, aiding in rapid diagnosis and targeted treatment.

questions.text: A patient presents with cervical lymphadenopathy and disseminated maculo-papules. He was investigated and found to be HIV reactive. Biopsy of skin lesions was cultured at 28° C and showed a velvety growth with red diffusible pigment on the underside as shown in the image. Which of the following is the likely dimorphic fungus the patient is infected with?
questions.solution:
• The patient presents with HIV, cervical lymphadenopathy, and disseminated maculopapular lesions, which are hallmark features of disseminated talaromycosis.
  • Talaromyces marneffeiis a dimorphic fungus that causes opportunistic infections in immunocompromised individuals, particularly in HIV patients.
  • Key culture features:
    • Grows at 28°C as a mold with velvety surface.
    • Produces a characteristic red diffusible pigment on Sabouraud Dextrose Agar (SDA).
    • At 37°C, it converts into a yeast-like form.

Incorrect Choices Explanation

  • Choice B: Blastomyces- Incorrect
    • Blastomyces dermatitidisis a dimorphic fungus, but it primarily causes pulmonary infections and broad-based budding yeasts at 37°C.
    • It does not produce red diffusible pigment in culture.
  • Choice C: Aspergillus- Incorrect
    • Aspergillusspecies are monomorphic molds that do not exhibit dimorphism (mold in both 28°C and 37°C).
    • They grow as filamentous fungi with conidial heads but do not produce red pigment.
  • Choice D: Pneumocystis jirovecii- Incorrect
    • Pneumocystis jiroveciiis a fungus-like organism, but it cannot be cultured on standard fungal media.
    • It is diagnosed using Giemsa or Gomori methenamine silver stainingfrom respiratory samples (BAL, sputum).
    • It causes Pneumocystis pneumonia (PCP)rather than skin involvement.

Key Takeaway

Disseminated talaromycosis should be suspected in an HIV-positive patient with skin lesions and a culture showing velvety growth with red diffusible pigment.

Reference: https://www.tandfonline.com/doi/full/10.1080/21501203.2017.1302013

questions.text: A patient presents with an itchy macule on the axilla for the last few days. On taking skin, scrapings, culture showed colonies that had red non-diffusible pigment on the under surface. LPCB stain showed septate branching hypha with pencil shaped macroconidia and a few microconidia. Which of the following is the etiologic agent?
questions.solution:
• The patient has an itchy macule in the axilla, suggesting a superficial fungal infection (dermatophytosis or tinea).
  • Key culture features of Trichophyton rubrum:
    • Produces red non-diffusible pigment on the underside of the colony.
    • Colonies appear white or buff-colored on the surface.
    • Lactophenol Cotton Blue (LPCB) stain findings:
      • Septate branching hyphae
      • Pencil-shaped macroconidia
      • Few microconidia
    • T. rubrumis the most common dermatophyte causing tinea corporis, tinea cruris, and tinea pedis.

Incorrect Choices Explanation

  • Choice A: Trichophyton violaceum- Incorrect
    • Produces violet/purple pigment, not red.
    • Typically causes tinea capitis and endothrix infection (hair shaft invasion).
  • Choice C: Trichophyton tonsurans- Incorrect
    • No red pigment production; colonies are variable in color.
    • Microconidia are abundant, but macroconidia are rare or absent.
    • Commonly causes tinea capitis.
  • Choice D: Trichophyton schoenleinii- Incorrect
    • Causes favus (severe chronic tinea capitis).
    • Does not produce macroconidia; instead, it shows antler-shaped hyphae ("favic chandeliers").
    • No red pigment production.

Key Takeaway

The presence of red non-diffusible pigment, pencil-shaped macroconidia, and septate hyphae confirms Trichophyton rubrum as the causative agent of dermatophytosis.

questions.text: A patient with poorly controlled diabetes is brought to the emergency with complaints of fever, cough and difficulty and breathing. He is diagnosed to be suffering with severe covid-19 infection. Due to persistently low oxygen saturation, he is started on high dose steroids. He started complaining of facial pain and loosening of teeth 5 days later. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Choice D: Mucormycosis (Correct)

  • Risk Factors:
    • Poorly controlled diabetes mellitus(especially DKA)
    • Severe COVID-19 infection
    • High-dose steroid therapy(causing immunosuppression)
  • Clinical Features:
    • Facial pain, loosening of teeth→ suggestive of rhino-orbital-cerebral mucormycosis.
    • Rapidly progressive infection affecting sinuses, eyes, and brain.
    • Black necrotic eschar in the nasal cavity(hallmark sign).
  • Pathogen:
    • Caused by Mucorales species(Rhizopus, Mucor, Lichtheimia).
    • Broad aseptate hyphae with right-angle branching seen on KOH mount.
  • Diagnosis:
    • Nasal endoscopy, biopsy, fungal culture, and imaging (MRI/CT showing sinus involvement).
  • Treatment:
    • Amphotericin B+ Surgical debridement.
    • Control of diabetes and withdrawal of unnecessary steroids.

Incorrect Choices Explanation

  • Choice A: Rhinosporidiosis- Incorrect
    • Chronic, painless polypoidal nasal mass caused by Rhinosporidium seeberi.
    • Does not cause acute facial pain, loosening of teeth, or necrosis.
  • Choice B: Coccidioidomycosis- Incorrect
    • Endemic to desert regions (Southwestern U.S., Mexico).
    • Causes pneumonia and disseminated infection but not aggressive sino-orbital disease.
    • Spherules with endosporesseen in tissue.
  • Choice C: Blastomycosis- Incorrect
    • Pulmonary symptoms + skin and bone involvement.
    • Broad-based budding yeast on microscopy.
    • No facial necrosis, sinus involvement, or rapid progression.

Key Takeaway

  • Mucormycosis is a life-threatening fungal infection seen in diabetics and immunosuppressed patients (especially post-COVID with steroid use).
  • Facial pain, sinus involvement, and necrotic lesions are key diagnostic clues.
  • Urgent antifungal therapy (Amphotericin B) and surgical debridement are critical for survival.

questions.text: A truck driver presented with cough and breathlessness. Chest x-ray showed right lower lobe pneumonia. Further investigation showed severe neutropenia. All bacterial cultures of sputum were negative. Lung biopsy histopathology showed dichotomous branching septate hyphae as shown in the image. What is the likely positive agent for the consolidation?
questions.solution:
Choice D: Aspergillus (Correct)

  • Key Diagnostic Features:
    • Dichotomous branching, septate hyphae at acute angles (45°)→ Characteristic of Aspergillus
    • Seen in lung biopsy histopathology, confirming invasive pulmonary aspergillosis (IPA).
  • Risk Factors:
    • Neutropenia (severe and prolonged)→ Major predisposing factor.
    • Immunosuppression (e.g., chemotherapy, organ transplant, corticosteroid use).
  • Clinical Features:
    • Fever, cough, pleuritic chest pain, hemoptysis.
    • Right lower lobe pneumonia on chest X-ray, which is common in IPA.
  • Diagnosis:
    • CT Chest:"Halo sign" (early) or "Air crescent sign" (late).
    • Galactomannan antigen test (serum or BAL fluid).
    • Culture of biopsy or BAL fluid for Aspergillus species.
  • Treatment:
    • First-line:Voriconazole + Echinocandin (e.g., caspofungin in severe cases).
    • Surgical resection in localized disease.

Incorrect Choices Explanation

  • Choice A: Rhizopus- Incorrect
    • Causes Mucormycosis, which presents with broad, aseptate hyphae branching at 90°, not septate hyphae.
    • Common in diabetics and immunosuppressed patientswith rhino-orbital involvement, rather than isolated pulmonary consolidation.
  • Choice B: Candida- Incorrect
    • Candida does not form septate hyphae in lung tissue.
    • Usually causes oral thrush, esophagitis, or disseminated candidiasis rather than pneumonia in neutropenic patients.
  • Choice C: Mucor- Incorrect
    • Broad ribbon-like aseptate hyphae with right-angle branching(not dichotomous septate hyphae).
    • More commonly presents as rhino-orbital-cerebral mucormycosis rather than primary pulmonary disease.

Key Takeaway

  • Invasive Pulmonary Aspergillosis (IPA) is a serious infection in neutropenic patients.
  • Histopathology showing acute-angle branching septate hyphae confirms Aspergillus.
  • Voriconazole is the drug of choice.

choices.text: Hepatic encephalopathy due to hepatitis A

questions.text: A 12-year-old presents with right upper quadrant pain, calf pain, conjunctival suffusion, icterus and fever. Examinations show tender hepatomegaly. No history of dyspnea, hemorrhage, oliguria and no travel history. Vitals other than that were normal. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Choice A: Leptospirosis (Correct)

  • Key Clinical Features:
    • Fever, right upper quadrant (RUQ) pain, icterus, conjunctival suffusion, and calf pain→ Classic presentation of Leptospirosis.
    • Tender hepatomegaly suggests hepatic involvement.
    • Absence of hemorrhage, dyspnea, and oliguria rules out severe complications like Weil's disease.
  • Pathogenesis:
    • Leptospira interrogans(a spirochete) is transmitted via contaminated water or animal urine.
    • It affects multiple organs (hepatic, renal, muscular) and can cause Weil's disease in severe cases.
  • Diagnosis:
    • Serology (IgM ELISA) or PCR for Leptospira.
    • Microscopic Agglutination Test (MAT) is gold standard.
    • Liver and kidney function tests may show transaminitis and mild renal dysfunction.
  • Treatment:
    • Mild cases: Doxycycline or amoxicillin.
    • Severe cases: IV penicillin or ceftriaxone.

Incorrect Choices Explanation

  • Choice B: Chikungunya- Incorrect
    • Classic symptoms: High fever, polyarthritis, rash.
    • No hepatomegaly, jaundice, or calf pain.
    • Joint pain is predominant, not RUQ pain.
  • Choice C: Dengue Hemorrhagic Fever- Incorrect
    • Classic symptoms: High fever, retro-orbital pain, rash, hemorrhagic manifestations (petechiae, epistaxis, GI bleeding).
    • No conjunctival suffusion or calf pain.
    • Severe cases show shock, which is absent here.
  • Choice D: Hepatic Encephalopathy due to Hepatitis A- Incorrect
    • Hepatitis A causes acute liver injury, but encephalopathy occurs in severe fulminant cases, which is not present here.
    • No mention of nausea, vomiting, or encephalopathy symptoms (confusion, altered sensorium).

Key Takeaway

  • Leptospirosis presents with fever, jaundice, conjunctival suffusion, RUQ pain, and calf pain.
  • It is diagnosed with serology (IgM ELISA) or PCR.
  • Treatment includes doxycycline for mild cases and IV penicillin/ceftriaxone for severe cases.

questions.text: A 30-year-old military Jawan presents with fever, myalgia and rashes all over the body, sparing the palms and soles. Similar complaints were reported in many of his fellow jawans. On physical examination, lice were noted on his body. Which of the following is responsible for his condition?
questions.solution:
Choice B: Rickettsia prowazekii (Correct)

  • Key Clinical Features:
    • Fever, myalgia, and widespread rash sparing palms and soles→ Suggestive of epidemic typhus.
    • History of lice infestation→ Rickettsia prowazekii is transmitted by the human body louse (Pediculus humanus corporis).
    • Similar complaints in fellow soldiers→ Indicates an outbreak, characteristic of epidemic typhus.
  • Pathogenesis:
    • Rickettsia prowazekiiis an obligate intracellular gram-negative bacterium.
    • The human body louse feeds on infected blood and transmits the pathogen via louse feces, which enter through scratched skin.
    • Vascular endothelial damage leads to fever, rash, and vasculitis.
  • Clinical Course:
    • Incubation: 1-2 weeks.
    • Symptoms:
      • High fever, severe headache, myalgia.
      • Maculopapular rash that spares palms and soles(unlike Rocky Mountain spotted fever).
      • Severe cases: Hypotension, meningoencephalitis, myocarditis.
    • Diagnosis:
      • Serology (Weil-Felix test, IFA, ELISA).
      • PCR for confirmation.
    • Treatment:
      • Doxycycline(first-line).
      • Chloramphenicol(alternative in pregnancy).

Incorrect Choices Explanation

  • Choice A: Rickettsia typhi- Incorrect
    • Causes endemic (murine) typhus, transmitted by fleas(not lice).
    • Mild disease with gradual onset(not epidemic outbreaks).
  • Choice C: Rickettsia akari- Incorrect
    • Causes rickettsialpox, transmitted by mites(not lice).
    • Presents with eschar at the bite site and vesicular rash, which is not seen here.
  • Choice D: Rickettsia conorii- Incorrect
    • Causes Mediterranean spotted fever (Boutonneuse fever).
    • Transmitted by ticks, not lice.
    • Rash involves palms and soles(not spared like in epidemic typhus).

Key Takeaway

  • Epidemic typhus is caused by Rickettsia prowazekii, transmitted by body lice.
  • Presents with high fever, myalgia, and maculopapular rash sparing palms and soles.
  • Doxycycline is the treatment of choice.

choices.text: GDH and toxin assay of stool

questions.text: A person with sepsis was admitted to the hospital and administered antibiotics for 10 days. He has developed watery diarrhea and dehydration. Which of the following is the best investigation to diagnose C.difficile infection?
questions.solution:
• Choice B: GDH and Toxin Assay of Stool (Correct)
    • Key Clinical Features:
      • Recent antibiotic use (10 days)→ Strong risk factor for Clostridioides difficile infection (CDI).
      • Watery diarrhea and dehydration→ Hallmark symptoms of CDI.
    • Best Diagnostic Test:
      • Glutamate Dehydrogenase (GDH) antigen test + Toxin assay (A/B) via ELISA
      • GDH detects C. difficile but does not distinguish between toxigenic and non-toxigenic strains.
      • Toxin A/B assay confirms active toxin production, which causes colitis.
    • Why This Test?
      • High sensitivity (GDH) + High specificity (Toxin Assay)
      • Rapid turnaround time.
      • Preferred over stool culture (slow) or microscopy (nonspecific).

Incorrect Choices Explanation

  • Choice A: Aerobic Culture of Stool- Incorrect
    • C. difficileis an anaerobic bacterium, making aerobic culture ineffective.
    • Even anaerobic culture is not routinely used due to slow growth and difficulty in distinguishing pathogenic from non-pathogenic strains.
  • Choice C: GDH Assay of Stool - Incorrect
    • GDH only detects C. difficile antigen, not whether it is toxin-producing.
    • A positive GDH test must be confirmed with a toxin assay.
  • Choice D: Stool Microscopy - Incorrect
    • C. difficiledoes not appear on routine microscopy.
    • Microscopy is useful for ova and parasites, but not for CDI.

Key Takeaway

  • GDH + Toxin A/B assay is the best diagnostic approach for C. difficileinfection.
  • GDH alone lacks specificity (detects non-toxigenic strains).
  • Toxin assay confirms active colitis.
  • Treatment: Oral vancomycin or fidaxomicin (preferred over metronidazole).

choices.text: Oral Fidaxomicin is used for treatment
Can be confirmed by using IgM assay
Pseudomembrane consists of leukocytes, fibrin and cellular debris

questions.text: A woman with a clinical history of diarrhea is on broad spectrum antibiotic therapy. Which of the following is not true regarding C.difficile?
questions.solution:
Choice C: Can be confirmed by using IgM assay (Correct - Not True)

  • Clostridium difficile infection (CDI) is not diagnosed using IgM assays.
  • CDI is diagnosed using:
    • GDH antigen + Toxin A/B assay (preferred)
    • NAAT (PCR) for difficile toxin genes (if needed for confirmation)
  • Why Not IgM?
    • IgM is used for detecting acute phase infectionsof systemic or bloodborne infections, like viral or bacterial serology (e.g., Hepatitis, Typhoid).
    • CDI is a toxin-mediated intestinal disease, and antibody detection is not useful for diagnosis.

Incorrect Choices Explanation

  • Choice A: It is toxin-mediated (True, Incorrect Choice)
    • CDI is caused by Toxin A (enterotoxin) and Toxin B (cytotoxin), which lead to:
      • Mucosal inflammation→ Watery diarrhea
      • Epithelial cell damage→ Pseudomembrane formation
    • Choice B: Oral Fidaxomicin is used for treatment (True, Incorrect Choice)
      • First-line treatment for CDI (along with oral vancomycin).
      • Fidaxomicinhas lower recurrence rates compared to vancomycin.
    • Choice D: Pseudomembrane consists of leukocytes, fibrin, and cellular debris (True, Incorrect Choice)
      • Pseudomembranous colitis in CDI consists of:
        • Dead epithelial cells
        • Neutrophils
        • Fibrin and inflammatory debris
      • This forms the "volcano lesions"seen on histology.

Key Takeaway

  • CDI diagnosis is not based on IgM assay.
  • Best diagnostic test: GDH + Toxin A/B assay.
  • First-line treatment: Oral Fidaxomicin or Vancomycin.
  • Pseudomembranous colitis is due to toxin-mediated epithelial damage.

questions.text: A teacher recently joined the school in the village and few days later developed rice watery stools. The causative agent acts on which of the following receptors to produce the actions?
questions.solution:
Choice A: GM1 ganglioside (Correct Answer)

  • The causative agent of rice watery stools in a newly joined teacher in a village suggests cholera (Vibrio cholerae).
  • Vibrio cholerae toxin (CTX) binds to GM1 ganglioside receptors on enterocytes in the small intestine.
  • This leads to:
    • Activation of adenylate cyclase via Gs protein
    • Increased cAMP levels
    • Secretion of chloride (Cl-) and water into the intestinal lumen→ Profuse watery diarrhea

Incorrect Choices Explanation

  • Choice B: GM2 ganglioside (Incorrect)
    • GM2 is not involved in Vibrio cholerae toxin action.
    • GM2 accumulation is seen in Tay-Sachs disease (Hexosaminidase A deficiency).
  • Choice C: Sphingomyelin (Incorrect)
    • Sphingomyelin is a component of cell membranes but not a receptor for cholera toxin.
    • Its accumulation is associated with Niemann-Pick disease(Sphingomyelinase deficiency).
  • Choice D: Cerebroganglioside (Incorrect)
    • Not involved in cholera pathogenesis.
    • Related to neurological disorders like gangliosidoses (e.g., GM1 gangliosidosis).

Key Takeaway

  • Cholera toxin (CTX) binds to GM1 ganglioside receptors.
  • Increases cAMP → Massive chloride and water secretion → Rice-water diarrhea.
  • Treatment: Oral rehydration, antibiotics (azithromycin, doxycycline in severe cases).

questions.text: What is the mechanism of action of botulinum toxin?
questions.solution:
Choice C: Inhibits the release of acetylcholine (Correct Answer)

  • Botulinum toxin (produced by Clostridium botulinum) blocks acetylcholine (ACh) release at the neuromuscular junction.
  • It cleaves SNARE proteins(e.g., SNAP-25, synaptobrevin, syntaxin) required for ACh vesicle fusion and exocytosis.
  • This leads to flaccid paralysis, seen in botulism(e.g., ptosis, diplopia, dysphagia, respiratory failure).

Incorrect Choices Explanation

  • Choice A: Stimulates muscarinic and nicotinic receptors (Incorrect)
    • Botulinum toxin does not stimulate receptors; it inhibits ACh release.
    • Stimulatory effects occur with cholinergic agonists (e.g., organophosphates, pilocarpine).
  • Choice B: Stimulates the release of acetylcholine (Incorrect)
    • Botulinum toxin inhibits, rather than stimulates, ACh release.
    • Black widow spider venom (α-latrotoxin) causes excessive ACh release.
  • Choice D: Stimulates muscarinic receptors (Incorrect)
    • Botulinum toxin does not directly stimulate muscarinic receptors.
    • Muscarinic agonists (e.g., bethanechol) act on muscarinic receptors.

Key Takeaway

  • Botulinum toxin blocks ACh release by cleaving SNARE proteins → Flaccid paralysis.
  • Used clinically to treat dystonias, hyperhidrosis, and muscle spasticity.

questions.text: A previously well 35-year-old man presented with high grade fever, severe body aches, headache, rigors and chills of 4 days duration. Dengue IgM and NS1 antigen, malaria and blood cultures were negative. A chance peripheral blood smear examination showed sheathed larvae with two nuclei in the tail tip. Etiologic agent is?
questions.solution:
Choice B: Brugia malayi (Correct Answer)

  • Brugia malayi is a filarial parasite that causes lymphatic filariasis.
  • Diagnostic feature: Microfilariae of B. malayi are sheathed and have two nuclei at the tail tip (a key differentiating feature from Wuchereria bancrofti).
  • Transmission occurs via mosquito vectors(Mansonia & Anopheles).
  • Common in Southeast Asia and India.
  • Symptoms include fever, lymphadenopathy, lymphedema, and elephantiasis in chronic cases.

Incorrect Choices Explanation

  • Choice A: Wuchereria bancrofti (Incorrect)
    • Microfilariae are sheathed but lack terminal nuclei in the tail tip.
    • More commonly associated with elephantiasis(chronic lymphatic obstruction).
  • Choice C: Loa loa (Incorrect)
    • Microfilariae are sheathed but have continuous nuclei(extending to the tip).
    • Causes Loiasis ("African eye worm") with subcutaneous swelling and migration across the eye.
  • Choice D: Mansonella streptocerca (Incorrect)
    • Microfilariae are unsheathed, and nuclei do not extend to the tip.
    • Causes skin disease rather than lymphatic filariasis.

Key Takeaway

  • Brugia malayi is identified by its sheathed microfilariae with two nuclei at the tail tip.
  • Distinguished from Wuchereria bancrofti, which lacks terminal nuclei.

questions.text: A photographer who recently returned from Egypt, presents with abdominal pain, hepatomegaly, hemorrhagic manifestations, renal dysfunction. He was given treatment. However, he deteriorated. On autopsy hepatocytes show intra-nuclear Torres bodies. Which vaccine could have prevented this?
questions.solution:
Choice C: 17D vaccine (Correct Answer)

  • The 17D vaccine is a live attenuated vaccine used for Yellow Fever, a flavivirus transmitted by Aedes mosquitoes.
  • Key Clinical Features of Yellow Fever:
    • Initial phase: Fever, hepatic dysfunction, renal involvement, and hemorrhagic manifestations.
    • Severe phase ("Toxic Phase"): Jaundice, renal failure, hemorrhage (black vomit), and multi-organ failure.
  • Autopsy finding: Torres bodies (intranuclear eosinophilic inclusions in hepatocytes) are seen in Yellow Fever.
  • Prevention: Yellow Fever vaccine (17D strain) is recommended before traveling to endemic regions (Africa, South America, parts of Egypt).

Incorrect Choices Explanation

  • Choice A: Nakayama vaccine (Incorrect)
    • Nakayama vaccine is used for Japanese Encephalitis (JE), not Yellow Fever.
    • JE is a mosquito-borne flavivirus but affects the CNS rather than the liver.
  • Choice B: Danish 1331 vaccine (Incorrect)
    • Danish 1331 vaccine is for Mycobacterium bovis (BCG), used against tuberculosis (TB).
    • TB does not present with acute hemorrhagic and hepatic manifestations.
  • Choice D: Jeryl Lynn vaccine (Incorrect)
    • Jeryl Lynn strain is used in the MMR vaccine(Mumps, Measles, Rubella).
    • Mumps can cause parotitis and orchitis, but not hepatic failure or hemorrhagic symptoms.

Key Takeaway

  • Yellow Fever is endemic in parts of Africa and South America, with hepatic failure, hemorrhage, and renal dysfunction.
  • 17D vaccine is the best preventive measure before travel to endemic areas.
